Proposed Equity Investment 
Aureos South-East Asia Fund II

other information referred to in paragraph 126 of the PCP.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 

 
A. 

I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 

1. 
equity investment of up to $15 million in Aureos South-East Asia Fund (ASEAF) II.  
 

II. 

THE FUND 

Investment Identification and Description 

2. 
ASEAF II is the successor fund to (i) ASEAF, an $86 million private equity fund raised in 
late  2004  to  invest  in  Indonesia,  the  Philippines,  Thailand,  and  Viet  Nam;  and  (ii)  Aureos 
Malaysia Fund (AMF), a $25 million private equity fund raised in late 2007 to invest in Malaysia. 
The  main  objective  of  ASEAF  II  is  to  further  develop  the  investment  strategies  pursued  by 
ASEAF and the AMF by investing in a balanced and diversified portfolio of small and medium-
sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  in  the  five  target  countries  of  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  the  Philippines, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam, with a secondary focus on Cambodia and the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic. ASEAF II’s target size is $180 million, and the fund manager will make growth capital 
and buyout investments in high-potential companies.  
 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has had a lengthy relationship with Aureos Capital 
3. 
that dates back to 1997, and has invested in four of its Asian funds: Aureos South Asia, ASEAF, 
Kula Fund I, and Kula Fund II. Aureos is thus well known to ADB, and vice versa. Aureos began 
exploring  a  potential  ADB  investment  in  ASEAF  II  as  soon  as  it  began  fund-raising.  Due  to 
resource constraints and a desire for additional visibility on exits from ASEAF, ADB waited for 
over  a  year  to  begin  processing  the  investment,  but  had  identified  ASEAF  II  as  a  potential 
investee throughout that time.  
 
B. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

4. 
Strategy. ASEAF II will pursue an investment strategy similar to that of ASEAF and the 
AMF  within  the  target  countries.  ASEAF  II  will  seek  to  make  investments  in  the  range  of 
$2 million–$10 million, each in a balanced and diversified portfolio of 20–25 established, high-
growth  businesses  with  expected  enterprise  values  of  $20  million–$100 million.  The  fund 
manager  will  focus  primarily  on  companies  servicing  domestic  demand  and/or  regional 
markets,  in  sectors  that  reflect  a  country’s  comparative  advantage. 1
 ASEAF  II’s  overall 
objective  will  be  to  generate  returns  by  making  minority  or  majority  equity  investments  in 
established SMEs led by experienced management teams. The fund manager expects to have 
effective management controls through minority shareholder rights and/or representation on the 
board of directors, and will have influence over the recruitment of key management staff. The 
fund  manager  anticipates  that  the  majority  of  investments  will  be  held  for  an  average  of  3–5 
years, in keeping with ASEAF II’s “buy and build” strategy.  
 
5. 
Deal sourcing. Investment opportunities will be screened by sector and across markets. 
In  addition,  analysis  and  assessments  will  be  made  by  reviewing  economic  and  development 
trends  across  target  countries,  and  engaging  in  proactive  research  and  top–down  analysis. 
Investment  opportunities  have  been,  and  are  expected  to  continue  to  be,  identified  in  the 
                                                
1  General  investment  sectors  include  fast-moving  consumer  goods,  retail,  restaurant  chains  and  franchises,  light 
manufacturing, distribution and logistics, support services, infrastructure, construction materials, business services 
related  to  information  technology,  business  process  outsourcing  and  “defensive”  sectors  such  as  health  care, 
education, and sanitation.  

 2 

 

following  ways:  (i)  direct  contact  with  business  owners,  (ii)  referrals  from  local  entrepreneurs, 
and  (iii)  referrals  from  local  financial  institutions.  In  Aureos’  experience,  SME  transactions 
throughout  the  target  region  are  relationship-driven,  therefore  Aureos  commits  extensive 
resources  to  building  and  maintaining  tailored  personal  relationships  with  key  executives, 
business  owners,  and  deal  providers  across the  target  region,  and the team members  have  a 
deep understanding of the target countries.  
 
6. 
Deal  structuring.  ASEAF  II  will  employ  a  flexible  approach to  structuring  investments, 
using a combination of equity, secured and unsecured debt, mezzanine debt, and quasi-equity 
instruments such as convertible loans and preference shares. Aureos expects to receive up to 
30%–40%  of  the  total  portfolio  cost  back  from  its  investments  in  the  form  of  cash  flows,  and 
believes  that  ASEAF  II  will  benefit  from  the  generation  of  these  early  returns  in  the  form  of 
scheduled contractual cash flows throughout the investment period, which mitigate currency risk 
and dependency on single liquidity events.  
 
7. 
Value  addition.  Aureos  believes  that  an  active,  hands-on  approach  is  essential  to  the 
development  of,  and  the  successful  exit  from,  its  investments  at  enhanced  valuations.  In  that 
context,  Aureos  will  focus  on  the  institutional  strengthening  of  portfolio  companies  to  meet 
international  standards,  including  strengthening  leadership  in  such  companies  in  the  following 
areas: 
(ii)  growth  strategies; 
(iii) operational  performance  improvements;  (iv) financial  management;  and  (v)  implementation 
of environmental, social, and governance standards. Aureos will seek to add value in particular 
by  helping  companies  with  regional  expansion,  leveraging  their  network  throughout  multiple 
countries in Southeast Asia.  
 
8. 
Exit. In Aureos’ view, investments in SMEs present a wide range of potential exit routes, 
principally  trade  sales  to  strategic  acquirers,  recapitalizations,  and  initial  public  offerings.  As  a 
consequence  of  these  multiple  potential  exit  routes,  companies  are  not  solely  dependent  on 
activity  levels  in  the  capital  markets  (although  all  five  main  target  countries  of  ASEAF  II  have 
relatively  liquid  stock  markets).  Aureos’  experience  demonstrates  that  a  key  determinant  of 
investment  viability  is  the  identification  of  an  appropriate  exit  strategy.  As  described  above, 
Aureos’ deal structures reduce the dependency on single liquidity events to generate returns, as 
a  significant  proportion  of  returns  are  generated  through  contractual  yields  as  well  as 
redemption through regular scheduled capital repayments of the debt portion of the investment.  
 
C. 

(i)  strategy,  management,  and  corporate  governance; 

Ownership, Management, and Governance 

1. 

Sponsor and Ownership 

ASEAF  II  is  sponsored  by  Aureos  Capital,  a  global  private  equity  manager  with  a         

 
9. 
19-year history of investing in SMEs in emerging markets. Aureos Capital was founded in 2001 
as a joint venture between CDC Group and Norfund, with the initial mandate to manage out an 
existing portfolio of 139 investments. In December 2008, Aureos staff completed a management 
buyout from the two founding shareholders and today retain 100% ownership of Aureos Capital. 
With over $1.3 billion in funds under management, Aureos has invested in 126 new transactions 
across  Asia,  Latin  America,  and  Africa,  with  a  current  realized  internal  rate  of  return  (IRR)  of 
over  30%.  The  firm  has  a  robust  infrastructure  for  SME  investing,  covering  over  50  emerging 
market  countries,  with  over  90  investment  professionals  with  experience  in  private  equity, 
commerce,  consulting, 
located  across 
investment  banking,  and  development 
29 locations  worldwide.  Aureos’  experienced  local  investment  professionals  have  broad  sector 

finance, 

 knowledge  and  strong  cultural  understanding  of  emerging  markets,  with  access  to  deep  local 
and regional networks.  
 

2. 

Governance Structure 

 
10.  Management. ASEAF II’s investment team comprises 18 investment professionals with 
extensive  private  equity  and  SME  business  investment  and  operational  experience.  The  five 
senior  team  members,  all  of  whom  have  worked  together  in  ASEAF,  have  a  deep  skill  set, 
including (i) a track record of successful exits in Southeast Asia; (ii) a skills base covering the 
full  range  of  SME  needs;  (iii)  a  wide  range  of  relevant  commercial  experience  gained  from 
investment, financial, and operational roles, ensuring a broad perspective on issues; and (iv) an 
extensive,  high-quality  contact  base  of  industry  executives,  providing  a  substantial  flow  of 
investment  opportunities  and  a  source  of  advice  from  sector  experts  at  both  pre-  and  post-
investment stages.  
 
11. 
Corporate  governance. ASEAF II will establish an advisory committee consisting of at 
least five members selected from among the larger limited partners. The advisory committee will 
consult  with  the  fund  manager  as  to  general  policies  and  guidelines  involving  the  changing  of 
auditors and valuation policy, prospective investment sectors, and conflicts of interest. ADB will 
have a seat on the advisory committee.   
 
12. 
Risk  management.  For  private  equity  funds,  risk  management  can  be  understood  as 
the process by which the fund in question selects, analyzes, structures, and exits investments 
(i.e., the investment process and policies that aim to identify risks, balance those risks against 
the anticipated returns of the investment, and mitigate the risks to the extent possible). Aureos, 
an  established  global  fund  manager,  adheres  to  a  structured,  consultative,  and  accountable 
decision-making  process.  Once  preliminary  due  diligence  and  pre-screening  have  been 
satisfactorily  completed,  the  team  proposing  the  investment  will  prepare  a  report  to  the 
investment  committee  for  consideration  outlining  the  investment  rationale  and  proposed 
structure, and will seek approval to conduct further due diligence. Once a transaction has been 
fully  negotiated,  which  may  involve  several  further  investment  committee  meetings,  the 
investment  will  be  presented  to  the  investment  committee  for  final  approval.  The  investment 
committee of ASEAF II will comprise six senior Aureos investment professionals.  
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

13. 
ADB  proposes  to  make  an  equity  investment  of  up  to  $15  million  in  ASEAF  II,  not  to 
exceed  25%  of  the  aggregate  capital  commitments  to  ASEAF  II,  whichever  is  less,  and  not 
resulting in ADB being the largest investor in ASEAF II. ADB’s equity contribution will be used 
exclusively for investments in ADB’s developing member countries.  
 
14. 
have a 5-year investment period, extendable by 1 year.  
 
B. 

ASEAF  II  will  have  a  10-year  life,  extendable  by  up  to  two  1-year  extensions,  and  will 

Implementation Arrangements 

15.  With regard to private equity fund investments, the term “implementation arrangements” 
refers to all processes and mechanisms used for investment performance monitoring, reporting, 
and evaluation. These processes and mechanisms include (i) financial monitoring—receipt and 

3 

 

 4 

 

review by ADB of quarterly unaudited and annual audited reports including financial statements, 
a  fund  overview,  and  an  overview  of  the  portfolio  companies’  performance  and  valuation; 
(ii) ADB  representation  on  ASEAF  II’s  advisory  board,  and  attendance  at  advisory  board 
meetings;  and  (iii)  non-financial  monitoring—receipt  and  review  by  ADB  of  ASEAF  II’s 
environmental  and  social  management  system  (ESMS)  and  annual  reviews  of  environmental 
and social safeguard issues. 
 
C. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

16. 
ADB’s assistance to ASEAF II is justified for a number of reasons: (i) demonstration and 
signaling  effect,  (ii)  market  development  and  catalytic  effect,  and  (iii)  ADB  portfolio 
diversification. 
 
17. 
Demonstration and signaling effect. Part of ADB’s role in capital market development 
is an effort to signal to the market its views on appropriate, viable business models. By investing 
in ASEAF II, ADB will send a signal to the market regarding the types of business models that it 
supports (i.e., funds with local teams and presence, track records, links with a global platform, 
strong  governance,  and  strong  environmental  and  social  safeguard  standards).  ASEAF  II  is 
backed  by  a  fund  management  platform  that  is  experienced  with  (i)  development  impact 
reporting,  and  (ii)  development  finance  institution  (DFI)-compliant  environmental  and  social 
safeguard  standards,  and  that  has  the  opportunity  to  leverage  and  replicate  successful 
experiences  in  non-Asian  emerging  markets  to  the  benefit  of  its  investees.  ADB’s  support  of 
ASEAF II will guide fund managers entering the market toward appropriate and attractive fund 
models for the region.  
 
18.  Market  development  and  catalytic  effect.  The  selection  of  ASEAF  II  results  from  a 
market  mapping  exercise  that  identified  Aureos  as  one  of  the  most  reliable  private  equity 
operators in the region. By supporting a reference player, ADB will continue to establish private 
equity in markets where it is still nascent. Also key to ADB’s added value in this transaction is its 
catalytic effect, i.e., the fact that ADB’s participation will help to attract additional investors and 
thus build deeper, broader, stronger private equity markets in this region. To ensure that ADB’s 
investment is indeed “catalytic” and serves as a genuine incentive to the fund manager to raise 
additional  capital,  ADB  has  structured  conditionality  into  the  investment,  such  that  $10  million 
will be committed up front, with an additional $5 million to be committed after ASEAF II achieves 
its minimum target of $150 million. 
 
Portfolio  diversification.  Since  2008,  ADB  has  added  to  its  portfolio  a  significant 
19. 
proportion  of  funds  managed  by  first-time  managers  and/or  focused  on  higher-risk  strategies. 
ASEAF II’s introduction into the portfolio will help to rebalance the overall risk profile with a more 
experienced fund manager  and  lower-risk,  sector-agnostic strategy.  Additionally,  ASEAF  II  will 
provide exposure to the high-growth markets of Southeast Asia, and will allow ADB to capitalize 
on  the  attractive  macroeconomic fundamentals  of  the  region.  Lastly,  analysis  of the  ADB fund 
portfolio  has  demonstrated  that  financially  successful  funds  are  generally  funds  that  achieve 
higher  development  impact.  Since  Aureos  funds  have  performed  better  than  average,  this 
implies  that their  development  impact  is generally  robust,  and they  are  anticipated to  maintain 
their performance with ASEAF II.  
 

 IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

A. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

The  impact  will  be  the  increased  availability  of  equity  financing  for  SMEs  in  ADB’s 
20. 
Southeast  Asian  developing  member  countries,  and  an  increased  contribution  of  SMEs  to 
economic growth and employment in Southeast Asia.  
 
The  output  will  be  the  establishment  and  investment  of  ASEAF  II,  which  will  be 
21. 
considered  successful  if  ASEAF  II  achieves  its  minimum  target  size  and  deploys  its  capital 
5 years after initial closing. This output will expand the number of profitable, well-governed, and 
environmentally responsible investee companies and SMEs in the target region (outcome). The 
logic of these links is further developed in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
B. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Alignment with Strategy 2020 

2. 

Consistency with Country Strategies 

Two key drivers of change in ADB’s Strategy 20202

The  proposed  investment  is  broadly  aligned  with  the  country  strategies,  which  target 

22. 
 are private sector development and 
operations,  and  good  governance.  ADB  is  dedicated  to  expanding  its  work  with  the  private 
sector  to  generate  greater  economic  growth  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  and  to  deploy  business 
management and technical expertise. Given ASEAF II’s focus on investments into high-growth 
sectors  of  the  real  economy  across  countries  in  the  region,  this  investment  is  closely  aligned 
with  this  objective.  Additionally,  because  ASEAF  II  will  sit  on  the  boards  of  its  portfolio 
companies  and  will  contribute  actively  to  their  governance,  an  investment  in  ASEAF  II  also 
supports the goal of contributing to good governance in the region.  
 
 
 
23. 
SME development as a strategic priority.  
 
Indonesia,  Malaysia,  and  the  Philippines.  In  the  Brunei–Indonesia–Malaysia–
24. 
Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area  (EAGA)  Roadmap  to  Development,  subregional 
cooperation  measures  were  identified  to  narrow  the  development  gap  across  and  within  the 
EAGA  member  countries  through  increased  trade,  investment,  and  tourism.  One  primary 
strategic  objective  articulated  is  to  “promote  intra-  and  extra-EAGA  trade,  investment  and 
tourism in selected priority sectors … with particular emphasis on SME development.”3
 Among 
the  measures  considered  are  (i)  advocacy  for  policies  favorable  to  business  development, 
particularly for SMEs; and (ii) improvement of the competitiveness of EAGA SMEs in the global 
supply chain.  
 
Thailand. The Greater Mekong Subregion Program (in which Thailand is a key member) 
25. 
emphasizes  SME  development  as  a  contributing 
to  well-integrated  economic 
development  in  the  subregion.  In  the  10-year  strategic  framework  for  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion for 2002–2012,4
 five development priorities were defined to help achieve its vision of 
                                                
2   ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  2008–2020. 

factor 

Manila. 

3   ASEAN. 2005.BIMP-EAGA Roadmap to Development 2006-2010. http://www.aseansec.org/18500-a.pdf  
4   ADB. 2002. Building on Success: A Strategic Framework for the Next Ten Years of the Greater Mekong Subregion 

Economic Cooperation Program. Manila. 

5 

 

 6 

 

a  subregion  free  of  poverty,  including  the  enhancement  of  private  sector  participation  in 
development, and improvement in competitiveness. Specific measures include capacity building 
for SME entrepreneurs, and the development of products and services that could support those 
entrepreneurs in cross-border trade and investment activities. 
 
26. 
Viet  Nam.  In  the  country  strategy  and  program  midterm  review  for  2007–2010  for 
Viet Nam,  the  government  acknowledges  the  importance  of  the  private  sector,  particularly 
SMEs,  in  advancing  the  country’s  development  objectives,  as  well  as  the  importance  of 
improving  access  to  domestic  financing  for  SMEs.  5 Viet  Nam’s  country  operations  business 
plan  for  2009–2011  addresses  some  of  the  regulatory  issues  related  to  SME  development  by 
prioritizing a second phase of its SME Development Program, through which policy reforms will 
be  supported  to  (i) improve  the  investment  climate  by  strengthening  investor  protection, 
enhancing  the  environment  for  competition  and  innovation,  improving  the  regulatory  review 
process,  and  reducing  transaction  costs;  (ii)  improve  trade  policy  and  facilitation;  and 
(iii) improve  macroeconomic  stability  to  support  economic  diversification  and  higher  private 
sector growth. 6
 
 

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

 

investment’s  potential  environmental  and  social 

ADB’s investment in ASEAF II is classified as category FI under ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
27. 
Statement  (2009).  The 
impacts,  risks 
associated  with  ASEAF  II’s  likely  future  portfolio,  and  its  commitment  and  capacity  for 
environmental management have been assessed. Areas where improvements are needed have 
been  identified,  and  effective  measures  to  address  them  and  ensure  compliance  with  the 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  have  been  laid  out  in  the  environmental  and  social  management 
system  (ESMS)  arrangement.  ASEAF  II  will  be  required  to  ensure  that  its  investments  are  in 
compliance  with  applicable  national  laws  and  regulations,  apply  ADB’s  prohibited  investment 
activities list, and establish and maintain an appropriate ESMS to manage the impacts and risks 
adequately, all in accordance with the Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
28.  With respect to gender, ASEAF II will invest in SMEs that may be owned by women, and 
the investments will facilitate the expansion of those businesses. With respect to job generation, 
women may be beneficiaries of the investments. ASEAF II’s investments in SMEs are expected 
to  generate  increased  employment  opportunities.  The  fund  manager’s  ESMS  will  include 
arrangements  to  comply  with  national  labor  laws  and  ADB’s  Social  Protection  Strategy 7
 to 
ensure  adherence  to  core  labor  standards,  including  provisions  prohibiting  any  discrimination 
against women in hiring and providing equal pay for equal work for men and women. ASEAF II 
will  include  information  in  its  annual  report  on  its  compliance  with  core  labor  standards  with 
respect to its investments.  
 
B. 

Anticorruption Policy  

ASEAF II was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) and its 
29. 
Policy on Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism (2003). ADB will ensure 

                                                
5   ADB. 2009. Country Strategy and Program Midterm Review: Viet Nam, 2007–2010. Manila. 
6   ADB. 2009. Country Operations Business Plan: Viet Nam, 2009–2011. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2001. Social Protection Strategy. Manila 

 that the investment documentation includes appropriate anticorruption provisions and remedies 
for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 

The proposed equity investment will be within the medium-term country, industry, group, 

30. 
and single investment exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 

C. 

Investment Limitations 

D. 

Assurances 

Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank, 8

31. 
 each country 
where ASEAF II invests will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to ADB’s proposed 
investment  in  ASEAF  II.  ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  finance  documentation,  in  form  and 
substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  following  approval  of  the  proposed  assistance  by  the  Board  of 
Directors.  

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

32. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  equity  investment  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $15,000,000 in Aureos South-East Asia Fund II, from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 

 

07 November 2011 

Haruhiko Kuroda  
President

DESIGN AND MONITORING FRAMEWORK  

Data Sources and 

Reporting Mechanisms   Assumptions and Risks  
 
 
Private equity databases

Activities with Milestones 

1. Operational arrangements 

Legal documentation (shareholders' agreement, subscription agreement, 
fund management agreement, etc.) are executed as appropriate by Q1 
2012. 

Incorporation, registration, and other activities needed to establish 
ASEAF II are complete by Q4 2009. 

2. Financing arrangements 

ADB invests $15 million by final closing of ASEAF II in Q1 2012. 

Fund manager invests 1% of fund size by final closing of ASEAF II in 
Q1 2012.  

Other investors invest up to $135 million by final closing in Q1 2012. 

3. ASEAF II activities 

ASEAF II promotes itself in the market, and attracts attention from 
companies on an ongoing basis (2011–2016). 

ASEAF II evaluates these opportunities and selects companies for 
investment as appropriate (2011–2016). 

ASEAF II adds value to investments over time (2011–2021). 

ASEAF II seeks appropriate exit opportunities, such as strategic buyouts 
or initial public offerings, and achieves exits from investments (2016–
2021). 

ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  ASEAF  =  Aureos  South-East  Asia  Fund,  DMC  =  developing  member  country, 
Q = quarter, SMEs = small and medium-sized enterprises. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
